climbs.name: Whoopsie Pillar
climbs.fa: Ben Stanton 1998 FFA (as per Kramar guide)

content.description: This line begins just right of a dirty crack system and ascends through steepening terrain (bolt and gear protected) to a powerful and thin crux at the third bolt. Memorable movement all throughout this fine line.
content.protection: 4 bolts, supplement with small to mid sized gear. Two bolt chain anchor.
content.location: Around the corner and uphill to the right of Ski Tracks (just uphill from Spring Cleaning)

content.description: Lieback a thin flake, fun move to exit it, and then head up highly featured slab to the first bolt (hard to see visible from ground). There's a couple more bolts and it heads up to some cool stemming off an arete before the chain anchors.
content.protection: Gear to 2" and a half dozen draws- no need to extend fully
content.location: Look for the big bush at the base of the wall- it has a small tree growing from it- around the corner and up the hill (climber's right) from Ski Tracks Crack. Chains visible from the deck if you step back from the wall.

content.description: Begin from belay platform moving up a left trending crack/flake to the first bolt, then up from there through blocky terrain with some fun movement up high as you move slightly back right to end in a small corner system with chain anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts, supplement with small to mid sized gear, chain anchors.
content.location: Around the corner and uphill from Ski Tracks.

content.description: Follow bolts up positive holds to a slab topout. Kramar guide suggests 10a as a rating, I suspect most would find this rating a bit soft. Nice short line with good movement and stone.
content.location: Uphill from Whoopsie Pillar (continue ascending on Ski Tracks Crag instead of walking over to Underhill)

content.description: Tricky moves off the ground lead to a shelf, then the real business of fingerlocks and thin hand jams up the rightward-leaning double cracks.  Very fun!
content.protection: Standard trad rack to about 3".  Anchor is a tree and a 60m rope is long enough to TR.
